metadata.source: Chapman, Chris; Withers, A.J. (2019). A Violent History of Benevolence
metadata.chapter: Chapter 1: Troubling the Standard Account of Social Work
metadata.note: All figures are complicit in interlocking systems of oppression - no moral judgment applied

historical_figures.name: Jane Addams
historical_figures.context: Hull-House co-founder, settlement house movement, NAACP member, eugenics supporter

historical_figures.name: Mary Richmond
historical_figures.context: COS, scientific casework, liberal individualism

historical_figures.name: Katherine Bement Davis
historical_figures.context: Bedford Hills Reformatory superintendent, eugenic criminology leader

historical_figures.name: Josephine Shaw Lowell
historical_figures.context: COS leader, eugenic criminology, Anti-Imperialist League, National Consumers League

historical_figures.name: Richard Henry Pratt
historical_figures.context: Indian Boarding Schools, 'kill the Indian, save the man'

historical_figures.name: Albert Rose
historical_figures.context: Africville/Regent Park relocations, U of T School of Social Work director, CASW president

historical_figures.name: Abraham Flexner
historical_figures.context: Professionalization, racist medical models

historical_figures.name: Oscar McCulloch
historical_figures.context: COS leader, The Tribe of Ishmael, eugenic propaganda, Indianapolis COS founder

historical_figures.name: Ida B. Wells
historical_figures.context: Anti-lynching activism, Southern Horrors (1892), radical social work

historical_figures.name: W.E.B. Du Bois
historical_figures.context: Radical activism, NAACP, supported feminism, Hull-House speaker

historical_figures.name: Maggie L. Walker
historical_figures.context: St. Luke Bank, financial autonomy, newcomer settlement social work

historical_figures.name: Zaynab al-Ghazali
historical_figures.context: Society of Muslim Ladies (Egypt), global non-secular community care

historical_figures.name: Janie Barrett
historical_figures.context: Locust Street Settlement for Black people, may predate Addams's services

historical_figures.name: Mary Ann Shadd Cary
historical_figures.context: Black community social services, media, integration and self-sufficiency advocate

historical_figures.name: George Haynes
historical_figures.context: National Urban League, Black social work education

historical_figures.name: Reverdy Ransom
historical_figures.context: Social Gospel, Socialism

historical_figures.name: Henry Bibb
historical_figures.context: Settlements, colonizer contradiction

historical_figures.name: Booker T. Washington
historical_figures.context: The Story of the Negro, visited Hull-House, assimilationist approach

historical_figures.name: Theodore Roosevelt
historical_figures.context: US President, capitalist, eugenicist, 1912 Progressive Party nomination seconded by Addams

historical_figures.name: Sir Francis Galton
historical_figures.context: Coined term 'eugenics' (1883), eugenic doctrine originator

historical_figures.name: Frederick Douglass
historical_figures.context: Abolitionist, supported feminism

historical_figures.name: Bayard Rustin
historical_figures.context: Civil rights organizer, supported feminism

historical_figures.name: James Baldwin
historical_figures.context: Writer, activist, supported feminism

historical_figures.name: Huey Newton
historical_figures.context: Black Panther Party, supported feminism

historical_figures.name: Malcolm X
historical_figures.context: Civil rights, Nation of Islam, anti-integration, assassinated before Africville emptied

historical_figures.name: Martin Luther King Jr
historical_figures.context: Civil rights, 'I Have a Dream' (1963), Nobel Peace Prize (1964), assassinated before Africville emptied

historical_figures.name: Rosa Parks
historical_figures.context: Montgomery bus boycott, NAACP trained organizer, staged civil disobedience

historical_figures.name: Claudette Colvin
historical_figures.context: 15-year-old who refused bus seat 9 months before Parks, Browder v. Galye plaintiff, teenage mom

historical_figures.name: Viola Desmond
historical_figures.context: Canada's Rosa Parks, jailed for sitting in segregated section in Nova Scotia

historical_figures.name: J.J. Kelso
historical_figures.context: Architect of Canada's Children's Aid Society system, aimed to convert Catholic children to Protestantism

historical_figures.name: John Edward Lloyd
historical_figures.context: Halifax Mayor during Africville destruction

historical_figures.name: Aaron 'Pa' Carvery
historical_figures.context: Final holdout in Africville, vacated 1970

historical_figures.name: Reverend William Baldwin
historical_figures.context: Toronto Associated Charities representative, advocated hard work to 'get rid of' vagrants

historical_figures.name: Elizabeth Jackson Shadd Shreve
historical_figures.context: Low-visibility figure mentioned as needing recovery

historical_figures.name: Jeffery Brackett
historical_figures.context: Baltimore COS and Children's Aid Society, credited with coining 'social work'

historical_figures.name: Simon Patten
historical_figures.context: Aligned with Addams, coined 'social worker' (1900), consumption education for poor

historical_figures.name: Philip C. Garrett
historical_figures.context: Chairman, wrote 'The Indian Policy in Its Relations to Crime and Pauperism'

historical_figures.name: Emma Goldman
historical_figures.context: Socialist and anarchist activist who was also a eugenicist

historical_figures.name: Mohandas Gandhi
historical_figures.context: Troubling relationship with 'untouchable' caste mentioned

historical_figures.name: Ernesto 'Che' Guevara
historical_figures.context: Argentinian Marxist revolutionary, Motorcycle Diaries, 'crossing the river' metaphor

summary.chapter_covered: Chapter 1: Troubling the Standard Account of Social Work
